Similarly, as we engage with farmers in regenerative ag practices and other programs, we can help them protect the future of their farms by improving soil and water health.

questions.e_prompt: Your customer responds, “I’m interested in learning more about how we can collaborate on scope 3 reduction goals. How does ADM interact with customers on achieving these goals leveraging regenerative ag?”
questions.e_instructions: What do you say? Choose the three best responses.

correct.e_text:

If the customer has a scope 3 reduction target, we then map and analyze the customer's business, e.g., what they are buying, where they are sourcing it from, and based on their supply shed, where ADM can provide solutions and implement regenerative ag practices.

Once the programs are implemented, we then measure and track progress and impact to provide reporting metrics and help the customer account for GHG inventory.

Regen ag and preventing deforestation are ADM’s big levers for helping customers reduce their scope 3. We implement the program in a tailored way that is linked to the customer's supply shed and sourcing areas. This is not just a one size fits all.

questions.e_prompt: A few hours later, you're in an internal meeting focused on a sustainability initiative. Your team member says, "I understand we need to account for our supply chain emissions and that what happens on the farm gets allocated to us. But why all this talk about what happens when our products leave our facilities? We’ve sold them. It shouldn’t matter to us.
questions.e_instructions: What do you say? Choose two best responses.

correct.e_text: The "cradle to gate" method means looking at a product life cycle to the point where we sell it to a customer, meaning where it starts (on the farm) to where it leaves our facility. In corporate GHG accounting, we need to use the “cradle to grave” method, which counts everything that happens from the farm all the way through the packaging or when the product ends up used or in a landfill. It even includes the emissions from companies we invest in!

incorrect.e_text: Consider corporate GHG accounting and ADM's responsibility for our products. Try again.

incorrect_second.e_title: Sorry, that’s still not quite right. The correct responses are shown.
incorrect_second.e_text:
Clarify that the largest source of scope 3 emissions is purchased goods and services, and employee or business travel has an extremely low impact on scope 3 emissions.

Also, you’ll want to encourage and commend your coworkers for thinking about the environment – every little bit helps – but use this as a pivot to what actually moves the needle for ADM. There are many things we can do as individuals. Keep the message positive and encouraging.

choices.e_text: I believe our scope 3 emissions are limited to sourcing and our upstream supply chain. We're not accountable beyond that.

questions.e_prompt: Your coworker then says, "That seems really unfair! correct.e_text: There will always be double and triple counting when we look at scope 3, but that’s the beauty of regenerative agriculture programs. Since ADM and our customers and their customers all have to count the on-farm emissions in our inventories, we can all take credit for the same reductions. If our growers sequester carbon in the soil and reduce their emissions, our scope 3 footprint goes down, our customers’ footprints go down, and the farmer protects and rebuilds his soil. It’s a win for everyone.

questions.e_prompt: You are now meeting with a farmer who says he’s heard about ADM’s USDA grant. He also tells you he’s seen articles about our partnership with companies like Pepsi and wants to know about the benefits with ADM’s re:generations™ program.

ADM’s re:generations™ is our regenerative agriculture program that involves working with farmers to implement a series of agricultural practices that have a positive environmental impact including improved soil health and water quality, and lower GHG emissions.

questions.e_prompt: The farmer indicates he’d like to learn more and asks, “What are the practices to follow and if I was interested, how could I get involved?”
questions.e_instructions: After explaining the key practices, what do you say? Choose the two best responses.

correct.e_title: Nice way to follow up with your customer!
correct.e_text:
ADM’s re:generations™ program is based on a set of key practices:

  • Maintaining living roots in soils

  • Minimizing soil disturbance

  • Continuously covering bare soil

These practices mainly involve the use of cover crops and implementing conservation or no-tillage.

We also focus on managing inputs responsibly, such as fertilizers and pesticides, and maximizing diversity through crop rotation and edge of field practices.

The ADM program is flexible so farmers can choose to start as simply as collecting data and/or implementing one or two practices.

To get started, farmers can contact their local origination manager who will collect some basic information and help them enroll via our digital platform.
